speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never trust my expectation.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Let there be the same net spread for her, and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of another’s dotage, and no such matter; that’s the scene that I would see, which will be merely a dumb show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Don Pedro, Claudio, and Leonato.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: This can be no trick: the conference was sadly borne; they have the truth of this from Hero; they seem to pity the lady. It seems her affections have their full bent. Love me? Why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censur’d; they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive the love come from her; they say too that she will rather die than give any sign of affection. I did never think to marry. I must not seem proud; happy are they that hear their detractions, and can put them to mending. They say the lady is fair; ’tis a truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; ’tis so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her folly, for I will be horribly in love with her. I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me, because I have rail’d so long against marriage; but doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age. Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the career of his humor? No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day, she’s a fair lady. I do spy some marks of love in her.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me. If it had been painful, I would not have come.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: You take pleasure then in the message?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knive’s point, and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, signior, fare you well.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Ha! “Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner”—there’s a double meaning in that. “I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me”—that’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

scene.scenedescription: Hero sends Margaret to fetch Beatrice and tell her to hide and eavesdrop on them in the orchard. When Beatrice sneaks in, Hero and Ursula spot her, and begin discussing Benedick and how deeply he is in love with Beatrice, as well as how the way she treats him is shameful. Once convinced that Beaatrice has been caught, they leave, and Beatrice decides that if they’re right, she will agree to marry Benedick.
scene.stagedir: Enter Hero and two gentlewomen, Margaret and Ursley.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor,
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.
Whisper her ear, and tell her I and Ursley
Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her. Say that thou overheardst us,
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles, ripened by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it. There will she hide her,
To listen our propose. This is thy office;
Bear thee well in it, and leave us alone.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: I’ll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit.
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid’s crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hearsay.
Now begin,
For look where Beatrice like a lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: The pleasant’st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait;
So angle we for Beatrice, who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful,
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: So says the Prince and my new-trothed lord.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it,
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,
To wish him wrastle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man;
But nature never fram’d a woman’s heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice.
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak. She cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endeared.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Sure I think so,
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she’ll make sport at it.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featur’d,
But she would spell him backward. If fair-fac’d,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antic,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agot very vildly cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out,
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: No, not to be so odd, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover’d fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Yet tell her of it, hear what she will say.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: No, rather I will go to Benedick,
And counsel him to fight against his passion,
And truly I’ll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with. One doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.
She cannot be so much without true judgment—
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is priz’d to have—as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted my dear Claudio.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: I pray you be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument, and valor,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Indeed he hath an excellent good name.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Why, every day tomorrow. Come go in,
I’ll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: She’s limed, I warrant you. We have caught her, madam.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: If it prove so, then loving goes by haps:
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemn’d for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And, Benedick, love on, I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand.
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.

scene.scenepersonae: (Prince Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Leonato, Don John the Bastard)
scene.scenedescription: Don Pedro and Claudio make fun of Benedick for showing signs of being in love, not least for having shaved off his beard. Benedick takes Leonato aside, and Don Pedro and Claudio are convinced it is to ask for Beatrice’s hand. Don John joins them, and tells them he has proof that Hero is unfaithful. He convinces them to watch outside her window that night, and both swear that if Don John’s allegations are proved, they will publically disgrace Hero in the church.
scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, and Leonato.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Arragon.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I’ll bring you thither, my lord, if You’ll vouchsafe me.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company, for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth. He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid’s bow-string, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him. He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: So say I, methinks you are sadder.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I hope he be in love.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Hang him, truant, there’s no true drop of blood in him to be truly touch’d with love. If he be sad, he wants money.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: I have the toothache.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Draw it.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Hang it!

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: What? Sigh for the toothache?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Where is but a humor or a worm.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has it.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Yet say I, he is in love.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises—as to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs. ’A brushes his hat a’ mornings; what should that bode?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Hath any man seen him at the barber’s?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: No, but the barber’s man hath been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuff’d tennis-balls.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Indeed he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Nay, ’a rubs himself with civet. Can you smell him out by that?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: That’s as much as to say, the sweet youth’s in love.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: And when was he wont to wash his face?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Yea, or to paint himself? For the which I hear what they say of him.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute-string, and now govern’d by stops.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Indeed that tells a heavy tale for him. Conclude, conclude, he is in love.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Nay, but I know who loves him.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: That would I know too. I warrant one that knows him not.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Yes, and his ill conditions, and in despite of all, dies for him.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old signior, walk aside with me, I have studied eight or nine wise words to speak to you, which these hobby-horses must not hear.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: ’Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this play’d their parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite one another when they meet.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: My lord and brother, God save you!

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Good den, brother.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: If your leisure serv’d, I would speak with you.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: In private?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: If it please you, yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I would speak of concerns him.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: Means your lordship to be married tomorrow?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: You know he does.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: You may think I love you not; let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage—surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestow’d.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Why, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: I came hither to tell you, and circumstances short’ned (for she has been too long a-talking of), the lady is disloyal.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Who, Hero?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: Even she—Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Disloyal?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness. I could say she were worse; think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till further warrant. Go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber-window ent’red, even the night before her wedding-day. If you love her then, tomorrow wed her; but it would better fit your honor to change your mind.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: May this be so?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: I will not think it.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know. If you will follow me, I will show you enough, and when you have seen more, and heard more, proceed accordingly.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: If I see any thing tonight why I should not marry her, tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: And as I woo’d for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses. Bear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue show itself.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: O day untowardly turn’d!

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: O mischief strangely thwarting!

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: O plague right well prevented! So will you say when you have seen the sequel.

scene.scenedescription: Dogberry and Verges, the captains of the Watch, organize their watchmen for the night, though Dogberry’s instructions leave rather a lot to be desired. Left to their own devices, the watchmen decide to sit on a bench until it’s time to go home. They overhear Borachio tell Conrade of the success of his plot, and how Claudio and Don Pedro are now convinced that Hero is unfaithful. Borachio has been well paid by Don John. The watchmen arrest the two for evil plotting.
scene.stagedir: Enter Dogberry and his compartner Verges with the Watch.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Are you good men and true?

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation, body and soul.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the Prince’s watch.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Well, give them their charge, neighbor Dogberry.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: First, who think you the most desartless man to be constable?

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Hugh Oatcake, sir, or George Seacole, for they can write and read.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Come hither, neighbor Seacole. God hath blest you with a good name. To be a well-favor’d man is the gift of fortune, but to write and read comes by nature.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Both which, Master Constable—

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well, for your favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there is no need of such vanity. You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lanthorn. This is your charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bid any man stand, in the Prince’s name.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: How if ’a will not stand?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Why then take no note of him, but let him go, and presently call the rest of the watch together, and thank God you are rid of a knave.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince’s subjects.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: True, and they are to meddle with none but the Prince’s subjects. You shall also make no noise in the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to talk, is most tolerable, and not to be endur’d.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: We will rather sleep than talk, we know what belongs to a watch.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend; only have a care that your bills be not stol’n. Well, you are to call at all the alehouses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: How if they will not?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Why then let them alone till they are sober. If they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Well, sir.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue of your office, to be no true man; and for such kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them, why, the more is for your honesty.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Truly by your office you may, but I think they that touch pitch will be defil’d. The most peaceable way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him show himself what he is, and steal out of your company.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: You have been always call’d a merciful man, partner.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more a man who hath any honesty in him.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call to the nurse and bid her still it.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Why then depart in peace, and let the child wake her with crying, for the ewe that will not hear her lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: ’Tis very true.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: This is the end of the charge: you, constable, are to present the Prince’s own person. If you meet the Prince in the night, you may stay him.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Nay, by’r lady, that I think ’a cannot.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Five shillings to one on’t, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him; marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: By’r lady, I think it be so.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Ha, ah ha! Well, masters, good night. And there be any matter of weight chances, call up me. Keep your fellows’ counsels and your own, and good night. Come, neighbor.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Well, masters, we hear our charge. Let us go sit here upon the church-bench till two, and then all to bed.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: One word more, honest neighbors. I pray you watch about Signior Leonato’s door, for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight. Adieu! Be vigitant, I beseech you.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: What, Conrade!

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Peace, stir not.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Conrade, I say!

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Here, man, I am at thy elbow.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Mass, and my elbow itch’d; I thought there would a scab follow.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: I will owe thee an answer for that, and now forward with thy tale.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Stand thee close then under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Some treason, masters, yet stand close.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Therefore know I have earn’d of Don John a thousand ducats.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich; for when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: I wonder at it.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: That shows thou art unconfirm’d. Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Yes, it is apparel.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: I mean the fashion.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Tush, I may as well say the fool’s the fool. But seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is?

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH
speech.line: I know that Deformed; ’a has been a vile thief this seven year; ’a goes up and down like a gentleman. I remember his name.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Didst thou not hear somebody?

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: No, ’twas the vane on the house.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is, how giddily ’a turns about all the hot-bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty, sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh’s soldiers in the reechy painting, sometime like god Bel’s priests in the old church-window, sometime like the shaven Hercules in the smirch’d worm-eaten tapestry, where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: All this I see, and I see that the fashion wears out more apparel than the man. But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Not so neither, but know that I have tonight woo’d Margaret, the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of Hero. She leans me out at her mistress’ chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good night—I tell this tale vildly, I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio, and my master, planted and plac’d and possess’d by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which first possess’d them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John had made, away went Claudio enrag’d; swore he would meet her as he was appointed next morning at the temple, and there, before the whole congregation, shame her with what he saw o’ernight, and send her home again without a husband.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: We charge you, in the Prince’s name, stand!

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: Call up the right Master Constable. We have here recover’d the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: And one Deformed is one of them; I know him, ’a wears a lock.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Masters, masters—

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: You’ll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Masters—

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Never speak, we charge you; let us obey you to go with us.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of these men’s bills.

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we’ll obey you.

scene.scenedescription: Hero prepares for her wedding with Ursula and Margaret’s help, the latter disagreeing with her over what she should wear. Saucy Margaret teases the bride, and makes great mock of Beatrice once she arrives. Beatrice is showing all the signs of being in love, and Margaret takes every opportunity for lewd comments she can get. She suggests that Benedick is ripe for marriage himself, despite everything. Ursula announces that the procession is ready to go to the church.
scene.stagedir: Enter Hero and Margaret and Ursula.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: I will, lady.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: And bid her come hither.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Well.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Troth, I think your other rebato were better.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: No, pray thee, good Meg, I’ll wear this.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: By my troth ’s not so good, and I warrant your cousin will say so.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: My cousin’s a fool, and thou art another. I’ll wear none but this.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner; and your gown’s a most rare fashion, i’ faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown that they praise so.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: O, that exceeds, they say.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: By my troth ’s but a night-gown in respect of yours: cloth a’ gold and cuts, and lac’d with silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel; but for a fine, quaint, graceful, and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on’t.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: ’Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Fie upon thee, art not asham’d?

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Of what, lady? Of speaking honorably? Is not marriage honorable in a beggar? Is not your lord honorable without marriage? I think you would have me say, “saving your reverence, a husband.” And bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, I’ll offend nobody. Is there any harm in “the heavier for a husband”? None, I think, and it be the right husband and the right wife; otherwise ’tis light, and not heavy. Ask my Lady Beatrice else, here she comes.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Good morrow, coz.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Why, how now? Do you speak in the sick tune?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Clap ’s into “Light a’ love”; that goes without a burden. Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Ye light a’ love with your heels! Then if your husband have stables enough, You’ll see he shall lack no barns.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: ’Tis almost five a’ clock, cousin, ’tis time you were ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill. Heigh-ho!

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: For the letter that begins them all, H.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Well, and you be not turn’d Turk, there’s no more sailing by the star.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: What means the fool, trow?

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Nothing I, but God send every one their heart’s desire!

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent perfume.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I am stuff’d, cousin, I cannot smell.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: A maid, and stuff’d! There’s goodly catching of cold.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: O, God help me, God help me, how long have you profess’d apprehension?

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Ever since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your cap. By my troth, I am sick.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Get you some of this distill’d carduus benedictus, and lay it to your heart; it is the only thing for a qualm.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: There thou prick’st her with a thistle.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Benedictus! Why benedictus? You have some moral in this benedictus.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Moral? No, by my troth I have no moral meaning, I meant plain holy-thistle. You may think perchance that I think you are in love. Nay, by’r lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in love, or that you will be in love, or that you can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man. He swore he would never marry, and yet now in despite of his heart he eats his meat without grudging; and how you may be converted I know not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Not a false gallop.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Madam, withdraw, the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch you to church.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

scene.scenedescription: Dogberry and Verges attempt to tell Leonato that they have some important information for him, but the longwinded Dogberry, continually interrupting Verges, so bores Leonato that the latter has to run to church. Needing to get to the wedding, Leonato tells the constables to examine their prisoners themselves, and leaves.
scene.stagedir: Enter Leonato and the Constable Dogberry and the Headborough Verges.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: What would you with me, honest neighbor?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you that decerns you nearly.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Brief, I pray you, for you see it is a busy time with me.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Marry, this it is, sir.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: What is it, my good friends?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter; an old man, sir, and his wits are not so blunt as, God help, I would desire they were, but in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living, that is an old man, and no honester than I.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Comparisons are odorous—palabras, neighbor Verges.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Neighbors, you are tedious.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the poor Duke’s officers; but truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Yea, and ’twere a thousand pound more than ’tis, for I hear as good exclamation on your worship as of any man in the city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: And so am I.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I would fain know what you have to say.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your worship’s presence, ha’ ta’en a couple of as arrant knaves as any in Messina.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: A good old man, sir, he will be talking; as they say, “When the age is in, the wit is out.” God help us, it is a world to see! Well said, i’ faith, neighbor Verges. Well, God’s a good man; and two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest soul, i’ faith, sir, by my troth he is, as ever broke bread; but God is to be worshipp’d; all men are not alike, alas, good neighbor!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short of you.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Gifts that God gives.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I must leave you.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: One word, sir. Our watch, sir, have indeed comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would have them this morning examin’d before your worship.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Take their examination yourself, and bring it me. I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: It shall be suffigance.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Drink some wine ere you go; fare you well.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I’ll wait upon them, I am ready.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole, bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail. We are now to examination these men.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: And we must do it wisely.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you. Here’s that shall drive some of them to a non-come; only get the learned writer to set down our excommunication, and meet me at the jail.

scene.scenepersonae: (Prince Don Pedro, Don John the Bastard, Leonato, Friar Francis, Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice, Attendants)
scene.scenedescription: The gathered assembly meets before Friar Francis, who begins the marriage ceremony. Claudio asks Hero whether she knows any reason they should not be married, and she insists that she does not. Claudio then rejects her, accusing her of immorality; the confused Leonato attempts to defend her, and shocked Hero protests her innocence, but neither Claudio nor Don Pedro will have any of it, both swearing that they saw her the night before at her window, talking with Borachio. Claudio’s insults, supported by Don Pedro and Don John, are so severe that Hero faints. The three accusers leave Leonato and his friends alone, Benedick remaining behind as well. Beside himself with grief and thinking himself dishonored, Leonato bewails the day and wishes that Hero were dead. Benedick attempts to find some evidence to clear Hero, but Beatrice cannot help, as she did not sleep in Hero’s room as customary the previous night. Friar Francis, however, is convinced of Hero’s innocence. Restored, Hero still insists on her innocence, having no idea what she’s being accused of. Benedick suspects Don John of being at the root of all this trouble, but Leonato is too confused to have an opinion, swearing vengeance on anyone who may have caused this. The Friar suggests that they announce that Hero died of grief and hide her away, giving time to find out what has happened and making Claudio pity her, while offering a way to sneak her off to a nunnery if she turns out to be guilty. Leonato and the Friar lead Hero away. Benedick attempts to console the tearful Beatrice. They slowly admit to each other that they are in love, Benedick finally offering to do anything for her as proof – at which she tells him to kill Claudio. Benedick refuses, and Beatrice’s rage bursts forth, as she wishes she were a man so that she could fight Claudio herself. Despite his friendship for the Count, Benedick promises to challenge Claudio to a duel.
scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Don Pedro, Don John the Bastard, Leonato, Friar Francis, Claudio, Benedick, Hero, and Beatrice with Attendants.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Come, Friar Francis, be brief—only to the plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: To be married to her. Friar, you come to marry her.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: I do.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not be conjoin’d, I charge you on your souls to utter it.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Know you any, Hero?

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: None, my lord.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Know you any, Count?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I dare make his answer, none.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: O, what men dare do! What men may do! What men daily do, not knowing what they do!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: How now! Interjections? Why then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Stand thee by, friar. Father, by your leave,
Will you with free and unconstrained soul
Give me this maid, your daughter?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: And what have I to give you back whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Nothing, unless you render her again.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.
There, Leonato, take her back again.
Give not this rotten orange to your friend,
She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O, what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,
All you that see her, that she were a maid,
By these exterior shows? But she is none:
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: What do you mean, my lord?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof,
Have vanquish’d the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginity—

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I know what you would say. If I have known her,
You will say, she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the ’forehand sin.
No, Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large,
But as a brother to his sister, show’d
Bashful sincerity and comely love.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: And seem’d I ever otherwise to you?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Out on thee seeming! I will write against it:
You seem to me as Dian in her orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown;
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus, or those pamp’red animals
That rage in savage sensuality.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: What should I speak?
I stand dishonor’d, that have gone about
To link my dear friend to a common stale.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: This looks not like a nuptial.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: “True”! O God!

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the Prince? Is this the Prince’s brother?
Is this face Hero’s? Are our eyes our own?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: All this is so, but what of this, my lord?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Let me but move one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: O God defend me, how am I beset!
What kind of catechizing call you this?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: To make you answer truly to your name.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Marry, that can Hero,
Hero itself can blot out Hero’s virtue.
What man was he talk’d with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now if you are a maid, answer to this.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: I talk’d with no man at that hour, my lord.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Why then are you no maiden. Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear. Upon mine honor,
Myself, my brother, and this grieved count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber-window,
Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,
Confess’d the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: Fie, fie, they are not to be named, my lord,
Not to be spoke of;
There is not chastity enough in language
Without offense to utter them. Thus, pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: O Hero! What a Hero hadst thou been,
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! Farewell,
Thou pure impiety and impious purity!
For thee I’ll lock up all the gates of love,
And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Hath no man’s dagger here a point for me?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Why, how now, cousin, wherefore sink you down?

speech.speaker: D. JOHN.
speech.line: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt Don Pedro, Don John, and Claudio.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: How doth the lady?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Dead, I think. Help, uncle!
Hero, why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: O Fate! Take not away thy heavy hand,
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wish’d for.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: How now, cousin Hero?

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Have comfort, lady.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Dost thou look up?

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Yea, wherefore should she not?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Wherefore? Why, doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?
Do not live, Hero, do not ope thine eyes;
For did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,
Strike at thy life. Griev’d I, I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal nature’s frame?
O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates,
Who smirched thus and mir’d with infamy,
I might have said, “No part of it is mine;
This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?
But mine, and mine I lov’d, and mine I prais’d,
And mine that I was proud on, mine so much
That I myself was to myself not mine,
Valuing of her—why, she, O she is fall’n
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again,
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Sir, sir, be patient.
For my part I am so attir’d in wonder,
I know not what to say.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: O, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: No, truly, not, although until last night,
I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Confirm’d, confirm’d! O, that is stronger made
Which was before barr’d up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who lov’d her so, that speaking of her foulness,
Wash’d it with tears? Hence from her, let her die.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Hear me a little,
For I have only been silent so long,
And given way unto this course of fortune,
By noting of the lady. I have mark’d
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes,
And in her eye there hath appear’d a fire
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool,
Trust not my reading, nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenure of my book; trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
Under some biting error.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Friar, it cannot be.
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury; she not denies it.
Why seek’st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Lady, what man is he you are accus’d of?

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: They know that do accuse me, I know none.
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy! O my father,
Prove you that any man with me convers’d
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintain’d the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Two of them have the very bent of honor,
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practice of it lives in John the Bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I know not. If they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,
Nor age so eat up my invention,
Nor fortune made such havoc of my means,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find, awak’d in such a kind,
Both strength of limb, and policy of mind,
Ability in means, and choice of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Your daughter here the princes left for dead,
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it that she is dead indeed.
Maintain a mourning ostentation,
And on your family’s old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs, and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: What shall become of this? What will this do?

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf
Change slander to remorse; that is some good.
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth:
She dying, as it must be so maintain’d,
Upon the instant that she was accus’d,
Shall be lamented, pitied, and excus’d
Of every hearer; for it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lack’d and lost,
Why then we rack the value; then we find
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio:
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
Th’ idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely organ of her life
Shall come apparell’d in more precious habit,
More moving, delicate, and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul,
Than when she liv’d indeed. Then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her;
No, though he thought his accusation true.
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be levell’d false,
The supposition of the lady’s death
Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you,
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: ’Tis well consented; presently away,
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.
Come, lady, die to live; this wedding-day
Perhaps is but prolong’d, have patience and endure.

scene.stagedir: Exit with all but Benedick and Beatrice.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: I will not desire that.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: You have no reason, I do it freely.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wrong’d.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right her!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Is there any way to show such friendship?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: A very even way, but no such friend.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: May a man do it?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: It is a man’s office, but not yours.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: I do love nothing in the world so well as you—is not that strange?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: As strange as the thing I know not. It were as possible for me to say I lov’d nothing so well as you, but believe me not; and yet I lie not: I confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sorry for my cousin.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Do not swear and eat it.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: I will swear by it that you love me, and I will make him eat it that says I love not you.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Will you not eat your word?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: With no sauce that can be devis’d to it. I protest I love thee.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Why then God forgive me!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: What offense, sweet Beatrice?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: You have stay’d me in a happy hour, I was about to protest I lov’d you.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: And do it with all thy heart.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Come, bid me do any thing for thee.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Kill Claudio.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Ha, not for the wide world.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I am gone, though I am here; there is no love in you. Nay, I pray you let me go.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Beatrice—

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: In faith, I will go.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: We’ll be friends first.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Is Claudio thine enemy?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Is ’a not approv’d in the height a villain, that hath slander’d, scorn’d, dishonor’d my kinswoman? O that I were a man! What, bear her in hand until they come to take hands, and then with public accusation, uncover’d slander, unmitigated rancor—O God, that I were a man! I would eat his heart in the market-place.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Hear me, Beatrice—

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Nay, but, Beatrice—

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Sweet Hero, she is wrong’d, she is sland’red, she is undone.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Beat—

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Princes and counties! Surely a princely testimony, a goodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant surely! O that I were a man for his sake! Or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into cur’sies, valor into compliment, and men are only turn’d into tongue, and trim ones too. He is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie, and swears it. I cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wrong’d Hero?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Enough, I am engag’d, I will challenge him. I will kiss your hand, and so I leave you. By this hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account. As you hear of me, so think of me. Go comfort your cousin. I must say she is dead; and so farewell.

scene.scenepersonae: (Dogberry, Verges, Town Clerk Sexton, Watch, Conrade, Borachio)
scene.scenedescription: Dogberry, Verges and the Watch bring Borachio and Conrade before the Sexton to interrogate them. Despite Dogberry’s inability to go about the interrogation properly, the story finally comes out, and the Sexton, who has heard of what happened at the church and thus knows that what was overheard is true, sends the prisoners to Leonato. Don John, it turns out, has fled.
scene.stagedir: Enter the Constables Dogberry and Verges, and the Town Clerk Sexton in gowns, and the Watch with Conrade and Borachio.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Is our whole dissembly appear’d?

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: O, a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: Which be the malefactors?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Marry, that am I and my partner.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Nay, that’s certain, we have the exhibition to examine.

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: But which are the offenders that are to be examin’d? Let them come before Master Constable.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Yea, marry, let them come before me. What is your name, friend?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Borachio.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Pray write down Borachio. Yours, sirrah?

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Write down Master Gentleman Conrade. Masters, do you serve God?

speech.speaker: BOTH CON. AND BORA.
speech.line: Yea, sir, we hope.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Write down, that they hope they serve God; and write God first, for God defend but God should go before such villains! Masters, it is prov’d already that you are little better than false knaves, and it will go near to be thought so shortly. How answer you for yourselves?

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Marry, sir, we say we are none.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: A marvellous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about with him. Come you hither, sirrah; a word in your ear, sir. I say to you, it is thought you are false knaves.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Sir, I say to you, we are none.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Well, stand aside. ’Fore God, they are both in a tale. Have you writ down, that they are none?

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: Master Constable, you go not the way to examine; you must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Yea, marry, that’s the eftest way; let the watch come forth. Masters, I charge you in the Prince’s name accuse these men.

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat perjury, to call a prince’s brother villain.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Master Constable—

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Pray thee, fellow, peace. I do not like thy look, I promise thee.

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: What heard you him say else?

speech.speaker: 2. WATCH.
speech.line: Marry, that he had receiv’d a thousand ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Yea, by mass, that it is.

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: What else, fellow?

speech.speaker: 1. WATCH.
speech.line: And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and not marry her.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: O villain! Thou wilt be condemn’d into everlasting redemption for this.

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: What else?

speech.speaker: BOTH 1. WATCH. AND 2. WATCH.
speech.line: This is all.

speech.speaker: SEX.
speech.line: And this is more, masters, than you can deny. Prince John is this morning secretly stol’n away. Hero was in this manner accus’d, in this very manner refus’d, and upon the grief of this suddenly died. Master Constable, let these men be bound, and brought to Leonato’s. I will go before and show him their examination.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Come let them be opinion’d.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Let them be in the hands—

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Off, Coxcomb!

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: God’s my life, where’s the sexton? Let him write down the Prince’s officer coxcomb. Come, bind them. Thou naughty varlet!

speech.speaker: CON.
speech.line: Away, you are an ass, you are an ass.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Dost thou not suspect my place? Dost thou not suspect my years? O that he were here to write me down as ass! But, masters, remember that I am an ass; though it be not written down, yet forget not that I am an ass. No, thou villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be prov’d upon thee by good witness. I am a wise fellow, and which is more, an officer, and which is more, a householder, and which is more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in Messina, and one that knows the law, go to, and a rich fellow enough, go to, and a fellow that hath had losses, and one that hath two gowns, and every thing handsome about him. Bring him away. O that I had been writ down an ass!

scene.scenepersonae: (Leonato, Antonio, Prince Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Dogberry, Verges, Watch, Conrade, Borachio, Sexton)
scene.scenedescription: Antonio tries to comfort the grief-stricken Leonato, but with little effect. When they cross paths with Don Pedro and Claudio, however, Antonio soon reveals that he is not as calm as he seems. Both brothers rail at the Prince and the Count, challenging them to fight, but the younger men refuse to duel with old men. Neither of them shows any remorse for Hero’s death, insisting on the truth of their accusations. Leonato and Antonio leave in a rage, and Don Pedro and Claudio try to cheer themselves up by conversing with Benedick, who now arrives. They joke about the old men, but Benedick does not laugh, instead taking Claudio aside and challenging him. Don Pedro mocks him about Beatrice, but Benedick does not rise to the bait, rather resigning from his service to the Prince. Don Pedro and Claudio realize that he is serious. As he leaves, they joke that he is simply henpecked, but then Dogberry and the Watch arrives, and the two men discover that they were in the wrong. Realizing that this is why Don John has fled, Don Pedro is stricken with remorse, while Claudio feels deeply in love with Hero once again. Leonato enters to hear Borachio admit his villainy to his face, and confronts Don Pedro and Claudio, who offer to do anything he asks to be forgiven, though insisting their actions were only wrong because their information was false. Leonato orders them to sign an epitaph to Hero’s grave, and to marry Antonio’s daughter. Cllaudio agrees. Leonato wishes to confront Margaret over her part in the plot, but Borachio insists that she is innocent and did not know what he was up to.
scene.stagedir: Enter Leonato and his brother Antonio.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,
And ’tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I pray thee cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless
As water in a sieve. Give not me counsel,
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so lov’d his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelm’d like mine,
And bid him speak of patience;
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus, and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form;
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
And, sorrow wag, cry “hem!” when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk
With candle-wasters, bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience.
But there is no such man, for, brother, men
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel, but tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion, which before
Would give preceptial med’cine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air, and agony with words.
No, no, ’tis all men’s office to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
But no man’s virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel,
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I pray thee peace. I will be flesh and blood,
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently,
However they have writ the style of gods,
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself;
Make those that do offend you suffer too.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: There thou speak’st reason; nay, I will do so.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince,
And all of them that thus dishonor her.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Don Pedro and Claudio.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Good den, good den.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Good day to both of you.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Hear you, my lords—

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: We have some haste, Leonato.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Some haste, my lord! Well, fare you well, my lord.
Are you so hasty now? Well, all is one.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: If he could right himself with quarrelling,
Some of us would lie low.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Who wrongs him?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou—
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword,
I fear thee not.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Marry, beshrew my hand,
If it should give your age such cause of fear.
In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me;
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag
What I have done being young, or what would do
Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,
Thou hast so wrong’d mine innocent child and me
That I am forc’d to lay my reverence by,
And with grey hairs and bruise of many days,
Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child!
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors—
O, in a tomb where never scandal slept,
Save this of hers, fram’d by thy villainy!

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: My villainy?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: You say not right, old man.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: My lord, my lord,
I’ll prove it on his body, if he dare,
Despite his nice fence and his active practice,
His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Away, I will not have to do with you.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast kill’d my child.
If thou kill’st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed;
But that’s no matter, let him kill one first.
Win me and wear me, let him answer me.
Come follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come follow me.
Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Brother—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Content yourself. God knows I lov’d my niece,
And she is dead, slander’d to death by villains,
That dare as well answer a man indeed
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.
Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Brother Anthony—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple—
Scambling, outfacing, fashion-monging boys,
That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,
Go anticly, and show outward hideousness,
And speak off half a dozen dang’rous words,
How they might hurt their enemies—if they durst—
And this is all.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: But, brother Anthony—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Come, ’tis no matter;
Do not you meddle, let me deal in this.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death;
But on my honor she was charg’d with nothing
But what was true, and very full of proof.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: My lord, my lord—

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: I will not hear you.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: No? Come, brother, away! I will be heard.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Now, signior, what news?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Good day, my lord.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Welcome, signior, you are almost come to part almost a fray.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: We had lik’d to have had our two noses snapp’d off with two old men without teeth.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Leonato and his brother. What think’st thou? Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: In a false quarrel there is no true valor. I came to seek you both.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: We have been up and down to seek thee, for we are high-proof melancholy, and would fain have it beaten away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: It is in my scabbard, shall I draw it?

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Never any did so, though very many have been beside their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels, draw to pleasure us.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: As I am an honest man, he looks pale. Art thou sick, or angry?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: What, courage, man! What though care kill’d a cat, thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and you charge it against me. I pray you choose another subject.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Nay then give him another staff, this last was broke cross.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: By this light, he changes more and more. I think he be angry indeed.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: God bless me from a challenge!

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: You are a villain. I jest not; I will make it good how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare. Do me right; or I will protest your cowardice. You have kill’d a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Let me hear from you.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: What, a feast, a feast?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I’ faith, I thank him, he hath bid me to a calve’s-head and a capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my knife’s naught. Shall I not find a woodcock too?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Sir, your wit ambles well, it goes easily.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: I’ll tell thee how Beatrice prais’d thy wit the other day. I said thou hadst a fine wit. “True,” said she, “a fine little one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.” “Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning. There’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour together trans-shape thy particular virtues, yet at last she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the proper’st man in Italy.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: For the which she wept heartily and said she car’d not.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Yea, that she did, but yet for all that, and if she did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly. The old man’s daughter told us all.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: All, all, and, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns on the sensible Benedick’s head?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Yea, and text underneath, “Here dwells Benedick the married man”?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Fare you well, boy, you know my mind. I will leave you now to your gossip-like humor. You break jests as braggards do their blades, which, God be thank’d, hurt not. My lord, for your many courtesies I thank you. I must discontinue your company. Your brother the bastard is fled from Messina. You have among you kill’d a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord Lack-beard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be with him.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: He is in earnest.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: In most profound earnest, and I’ll warrant you, for the love of Beatrice.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: And hath challeng’d thee?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Most sincerely.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

scene.stagedir: Enter Constables Dogberry and Verges, and the Watch with Conrade and Borachio.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: He is then a giant to an ape, but then is an ape a doctor to such a man.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: But soft you, let me be. Pluck up, my heart, and be sad. Did he not say my brother was fled?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Come you, sir. If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne’er weigh more reasons in her balance. Nay, and you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be look’d to.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: How now? Two of my brother’s men bound? Borachio one!

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Hearken after their offense, my lord.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Officers, what offense have these men done?

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixt and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and to conclude, they are lying knaves.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee what’s their offense; sixt and lastly, why they are committed; and to conclude, what you lay to their charge.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Rightly reason’d, and in his own division, and by my troth there’s one meaning well suited.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Who have you offended, masters, that you are thus bound to your answer? This learned constable is too cunning to be understood. What’s your offense?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Sweet Prince, let me go no farther to mine answer: do you hear me, and let this count kill me. I have deceiv’d even your very eyes. What your wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools have brought to light, who in the night overheard me confessing to this man how Don John your brother incens’d me to slander the Lady Hero, how you were brought into the orchard, and saw me court Margaret in Hero’s garments, how you disgrac’d her when you should marry her. My villainy they have upon record, which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame. The lady is dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation; and briefly, I desire nothing but the reward of a villain.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I have drunk poison whiles he utter’d it.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: But did my brother set thee on to this?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: He is compos’d and fram’d of treachery,
And fled he is upon this villainy.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I lov’d it first.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Come, bring away the plaintiffs. By this time our sexton hath reform’d Signior Leonato of the matter; and, masters, do not forget to specify, when time and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

speech.speaker: VERG.
speech.line: Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the sexton too.

scene.stagedir: Enter Leonato, his brother Antonio, and the Sexton.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Which is the villain? Let me see his eyes,
That when I note another man like him
I may avoid him. Which of these is he?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast kill’d
Mine innocent child?

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: Yea, even I alone.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
Here stand a pair of honorable men,
A third is fled, that had a hand in it.
I thank you, princes, for my daughter’s death;
Record it with your high and worthy deeds.
’Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself,
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin; yet sinn’d I not,
But in mistaking.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: By my soul, nor I,
And yet, to satisfy this good old man,
I would bend under any heavy weight
That he’ll enjoin me to.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live—
That were impossible—but I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here
How innocent she died, and if your love
Can labor aught in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb,
And sing it to her bones, sing it tonight.
Tomorrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my nephew. My brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that’s dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us.
Give her the right you should have giv’n her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: O noble sir!
Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
I do embrace your offer, and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming,
Tonight I take my leave. This naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was pack’d in all this wrong,
Hir’d to it by your brother.

speech.speaker: BORA.
speech.line: No, by my soul she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous
In any thing that I do know by her.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white and black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call me ass. I beseech you let it be rememb’red in his punishment. And also, the watch heard them talk of one Deformed. They say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it, and borrows money in God’s name, the which he hath us’d so long and never paid that now men grow hard-hearted and will lend nothing for God’s sake. Pray you examine him upon that point.

speech.speaker: LEON.
