speech.line: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: There’s for thy pains.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: God save the foundation!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.

speech.speaker: DOG.
speech.line: I leave an arrant knave with your worship, which I beseech your worship to correct yourself, for the example of others. God keep your worship! I wish your worship well. God restore you to health! I humbly give you leave to depart, and if a merry meeting may be wish’d, God prohibit it! Come, neighbor.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Until tomorrow morning, lords, farewell.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Farewell, my lords, we look for you tomorrow.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: We will not fail.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Tonight I’ll mourn with Hero.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Bring you these fellows on.—We’ll talk with Margaret,
How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

scene.scenedescription: Benedick and Margaret jest together; she leaves to call Beatrice for him. While waiting for her, Benedick reflects on his utter inability to write poetry. Beatrice arrives, and though they immediately start sparring, he manages to inform her of Claudio’s acceptance of his challenge. Both insist that they are in love against their will. Ursula suddenly bursts in with the news that Hero’s innocence has been proved, and they rush to find out more.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come over it, for in most comely truth thou deservest it.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: To have no man come over me? Why, shall I always keep below stairs?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound’s mouth, it catches.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: And yours as blunt as the fencer’s foils, which hit, but hurt not.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman. And so I pray thee call Beatrice; I give thee the bucklers.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Give us the swords, we have bucklers of our own.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for maids.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: And therefore will come.
“The god of love,
That sits above,
And knows me, and knows me,
How pitiful I deserve”—

I mean in singing; but in loving, Leander the good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of pandars, and a whole bookful of these quondam carpet-mongers, whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a blank verse, why, they were never so truly turn’d over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I cannot show it in rhyme; I have tried. I can find out no rhyme to “lady” but “baby,” an innocent rhyme; for “scorn,” “horn,” a hard rhyme; for “school,” “fool,” a babbling rhyme: very ominous endings. No, I was not born under a rhyming planet, nor I cannot woo in festival terms.
Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I call’d thee?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Yea, signior, and depart when you bid me.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: O, stay but till then!

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: “Then” is spoken; fare you well now. And yet ere I go, let me go with that I came, which is, with knowing what hath pass’d between you and Claudio.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Only foul words—and thereupon I will kiss thee.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome; therefore I will depart unkiss’d.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward. And I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: For them all together, which maintain’d so politic a state of evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them. But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love for me?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Suffer love! A good epithite! I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: In spite of your heart, I think. Alas, poor heart, if you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for I will never love that which my friend hates.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: It appears not in this confession; there’s not one wise man among twenty that will praise himself.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that liv’d in the time of good neighbors. If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widowweeps.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: And how long is that, think you?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum; therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm (his conscience) find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for praising myself, who I myself will bear witness is praiseworthy. And now tell me, how doth your cousin?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Very ill.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: And how do you?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Very ill too.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Serve God, love me, and mend. There will I leave you too, for here comes one in haste.

speech.speaker: URS.
speech.line: Madam, you must come to your uncle, yonder’s old coil at home. It is prov’d my Lady Hero hath been falsely accus’d, the Prince and Claudio mightily abus’d, and Don John is the author of all, who is fled and gone. Will you come presently?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Will you go hear this news, signior?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy eyes; and moreover I will go with thee to thy uncle’s.

scene.scenedescription: Before the tomb of Leonato’s family, Claudio reads out his epitaph for Hero, and vows to perform the rite once a year. With Don Pedro, he goes to prepare for the wedding in the morning.
scene.stagedir: Enter Claudio, Prince Don Pedro, and three or four with tapers.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Is this the monument of Leonato?

speech.speaker: A LORD.
speech.line: It is, my lord.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.

line.recite: Was the Hero that here lies.
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies.
So the life that died with shame
Lives in death with glorious fame.”
Hang thou there upon the tomb,

speech.line: Praising her when I am dumb.
Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
Pardon, goddess of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
For the which, with songs of woe,
Round about her tomb they go.
Midnight, assist our moan,
Help us to sigh and groan,
Heavily, heavily.
Graves, yawn and yield your dead,
Till death be uttered,
Heavily, heavily.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Now, unto thy bones good night!
Yearly will I do this rite.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Good morrow, masters, put your torches out.
The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day,
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
Thanks to you all, and leave us. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Good morrow, masters—each his several way.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Come let us hence, and put on other weeds,
And then to Leonato’s we will go.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: And Hymen now with luckier issue speed’s
Than this for whom we rend’red up this woe.

scene.scenepersonae: (Leonato, Benedick, Beatrice, Margaret, Ursula, Antonio, Friar Francis, Hero, Prince Don Pedro, Claudio, Messenger)
scene.scenedescription: Friar Francis, Leonato, Antonio and Benedick reflect on what has been learned, excusing the Prince and Claudio; Benedick is glad that he will no longer have to fight Claudio. They send the ladies away with instructions to return masked when they are called for. Benedick asks Leonato for Beatrice’s hand. Don Pedro and Claudio arrive in good spirits. Claudio reaffirms his willingness to marry whichever lady is given to him, and the masked ladies enter. Before he is allowed to see her face, Claudio takes Hero by the hand and swears to marry her – and then he discovers that she is the still-living Hero. Friar Francis offers to explain everything once the marriage is over, but before they can make their way to the church, Benedick publically asks Beatrice whether she loves him. She denies it as much as he denies loving her, while they work out that they have been set up. They decide to marry nevertheless, and Don Pedro mocks Benedick for marrying, despite all his promises, but Benedick will not rise to the bait and instead urges the Prince to marry as well. Benedick insists that they dance before getting married, though Leonato thinks it more proper to wait till after. News comes that Don John has been captured, but Benedick tells people to forget about him until the next day, and they all begin to dance.
scene.stagedir: Enter Leonato, Benedick, Beatrice, Margaret, Ursula, old man Antonio, Friar Francis, Hero.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: So are the Prince and Claudio, who accus’d her
Upon the error that you heard debated.
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will, as it appears
In the true course of all the question.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Well, I am glad that all things sorts so well.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: And so am I, being else by faith enforc’d
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you, come hither masked.
The Prince and Claudio promis’d by this hour
To visit me. You know your office, brother:
You must be father to your brother’s daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Which I will do with confirm’d countenance.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: To do what, signior?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: To bind me, or undo me—one of them.
Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favor.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: That eye my daughter lent her, ’tis most true.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio, and the Prince. But what’s your will?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical,
But for my will, my will is your good will
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin’d
In the state of honorable marriage,
In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: My heart is with your liking.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: And my help.
Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Don Pedro and Claudio and two or three other.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio;
We here attend you. Are you yet determined
Today to marry with my brother’s daughter?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Call her forth, brother, here’s the friar ready.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what’s the matter,
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness?

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
Tush, fear not, man, we’ll tip thy horns with gold,
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Jove,
When he would play the noble beast in love.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low,
And some such strange bull leapt your father’s cow,
And got a calf in that same noble feat
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

scene.stagedir: Enter Brother Antonio, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Ursula, the ladies masked.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: For this I owe you: here comes other reck’nings.
Which is the lady I must seize upon?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: This same is she, and I do give you her.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Why then she’s mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: No, that you shall not till you take her hand,
Before this friar, and swear to marry her.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Give me your hand before this holy friar—
I am your husband if you like of me.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: And when I liv’d, I was your other wife,
And when you lov’d, you were my other husband.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: Another Hero!

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: Nothing certainer:
One Hero died defil’d, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander liv’d.

speech.speaker: FRIAR.
speech.line: All this amazement can I qualify,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
I’ll tell you largely of fair Hero’s death.
Mean time let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I answer to that name. What is your will?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Do not you love me?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Why, no, no more than reason.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Why then your uncle and the Prince and Claudio
Have been deceived. They swore you did.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Do not you love me?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Troth, no, no more than reason.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: Why then my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula
Are much deceiv’d, for they did swear you did.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: ’Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: And I’ll be sworn upon’t that he loves her,
For here’s a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashion’d to Beatrice.

speech.speaker: HERO.
speech.line: And here’s another
Writ in my cousin’s hand, stol’n from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedick.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: A miracle! Here’s our own hands against our hearts. Come, I will have thee, but by this light, I take thee for pity.

speech.speaker: BEAT.
speech.line: I would not deny you, but by this good day, I yield upon great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told you were in a consumption.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Peace, I will stop your mouth.

speech.speaker: D. PEDRO.
speech.line: How dost thou, Benedick the married man?

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: I’ll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humor. Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram? No, if a man will be beaten with brains, ’a shall wear nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that the world can say against it, and therefore never flout at me for what I have said against it; for man is a giddy thing, and this is my conclusion. For thy part, Claudio, I did think to have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman, live unbruis’d, and love my cousin.

speech.speaker: CLAUD.
speech.line: I had well hop’d thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I might have cudgell’d thee out of thy single life, to make thee a double-dealer, which out of question thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look exceeding narrowly to thee.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Come, come, we are friends. Let’s have a dance ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts and our wives’ heels.

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: We’ll have dancing afterward.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: First, of my word; therefore play, music. Prince, thou art sad, get thee a wife, get thee a wife. There is no staff more reverent than one tipp’d with horn.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: My lord, your brother John is ta’en in flight,
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

speech.speaker: BENE.
speech.line: Think not on him till tomorrow. I’ll devise thee brave punishments for him. Strike up, pipers.
